Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Multiflagellar Swimming in Bacteria
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the investigators will focus on development of biophysical models of multiflagellar locomotion in bacteria and use of the models to gain an understanding of the principles underlying locomotion phenomena. They will explore the parameter and design space, to help build an understanding of how the biological systems evolved to become the way they are. Principal aims include the development of mechanistic models for the dynamics of multiflagellar locomotion at a number of levels of description, and application of these models toward understanding various observations of bacterial swimming. In particular, one broad theme that appears upon examination of the experimental observations is multiplicity. Why are there multiple modes of bacterial swimming? Why do many species have capabilities to swim with multiple flagellar modes? Is one of the selective advantages of multiflagellar swimming the multiple possible configurations of the flagella? The proposed work will begin to systematically address this theme by building and applying models that begin to approach the physical complexity of a real multiflagellar organism, will substantially advance this understanding, contributing not only to fundamental microbiology but to many applications, such as soil remediation and prevention of infections, that are closely linked to bacterial motility. By shedding light on how bacteria swim, the proposed work will also strengthen the intellectual foundations for development of artificial microscopic swimming machines. The graduate students who will be educated during the conduct of this research will gain a unique combination of expertise in biophysics and computational mechanics. As part of the present project, in addition to participating in the proposed research, undergraduates will be involved in a K-12 outreach project involving the Boys and Girls Club of Dane County.

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Cellular Dynamics and Function Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

To sample and respond to their environments, motile microorganisms display a wide variety of mechanisms for propelling themselves in fluid. Many species, such as E. coli, have a large number of long flagella that dynamically assemble into bundles as they rotate, and it is these bundles that propel the microorganism through fluid. Others, including Vibrio parahaemolyticus, which causes seafood poisoning, display many flagella under some circumstances but only a single flagellum with different morphology under others. Presumably, the diverse array of morphologies that is found has evolved because there are selective advantages to different schemes in different environments, but the origin of this diversity is as yet unknown. One reason (among many) for this lack of understanding is that the only means of flagellar propulsion whose mechanics is well-understood is that due to a single flagellum, whereas many common motile bacteria have multiple flagella. Therefore, a frontier problem in the physical biology of microorganisms is the locomotion of multiflagellar prokaryotes.

The work performed under this grant focused on development of biophysical models of multiflagellar locomotion in bacteria and  use of the models to gain an understanding of the principles underlying locomotion phenomena. Principal aims included the development of mechanistic models for the dynamics of multiflagellar locomotion at a number of levels of description, and application of these models toward understanding various observations of bacterial swimming. 

Many bacterial species have one or several flagella each connected to a rotary motor in the bacterial cell wall by a protein linker called a hook.  Using a simple mathematical model of a cell with a single flagellum, we have computed the parameter regime in which the cell can undergo stable straight swimming. Outside this regime, the flagellar hook undergoes a buckling instability that leads to different types of swimming depending of the details of the hook mechanics. In some cases, a helical swimming pattern emerges, while in others a "flicking" motion of the flagellum occurs. Both of these swimming modes have recently been observed in experiments. A more detailed bacterial model that incorporates multiple flagella has also been developed.   With this model we have shown that while multiflagellar swimming is not substantially faster than uniflagellar swimming,  multiflagellarity confers substantial stability.  A bacterium whose flagellar hook is too flexible to support uniflagellar swimming without incurring a buckling instability is often able to swim stably when equipped with two flagella (see figures).  This result indicates one potential selective advantage to multiflagellar bacterial phenotypes. 

Broader impacts

The physical understanding of the relationship between bacterial morphology and locomotion is presently very limited. The present work, by building and applying models that that begin to approach the physical complexity of a real multiflagellar organism,  substantially advances this understanding, contributing not only to fundamental microbiology but to many applications, such as soil remediation and prevention of infections, that are closely linked to bacterial motility.   By shedding light on how bacteria swim, this work has also strengthened the intellectual foundations for development of artificial microscopic swimming machines.  

As part of this project, the principal investigator co-developed a new undergraduate engineering course ``Chemical Engineering in the Community''. In this course, undersgraduate students developed age-appropriate fluid-mechanics-based educational activities for K-12 kids and went to the Boys and Girls Club of Dane County to perform the activities with the kids. This project has run three times over the duration of the grant and is will continue in future semesters.
